data.text: @ahow628 @bennyfactor I like Brohm-ball. Dang it, he's good.
@bennyfactor @ahow628 U of Chicago has an all-time winning record against Indiana. They were smart enough to quit while they were ahead.

@urbanindy @ahow628 I feel you. Of the 3 institutes of higher education I attended, one has an all-time .500 record in D2 or whatever, one is in the D1 b-league, and the third sold "Undefeated since 1930" football shirts while I attended because that was the last year they had a team.

@bennyfactor @ahow628 Yes. That's fine.

Fortunately, my college football team is historically awful, and yet they still find new and fun ways to lose every year!
@urbanindy @ahow628 But yeah I agree about 1000 yr locust plague > thou ohio state universiteee

@urbanindy @ahow628 I care very little about college football generally (and even less about professional except as a statistical source for fantasy football) but have a vague sense of attachment to ND & them playing UM from childhood. Also they are both good academic institutions so that is a plus.

@ahow628 @bennyfactor worst midwestern teams:
4. UM
3. ND
2. a thousand year plague of locusts
1. OSU

Sports opinions!10101!

@northumbriana Those look great with the exception of the corporate branding.  Our team in the USL has gaudy logos for Honda (which has a plant about an hour from here) and also for Turkish Airlines, which doesn't even fly here https://t.co/Bc6CdEKovK

@bennyfactor Football teams over here chop and change their ‘away’ strips all the time. NUFC recently brought back a favourite from the 90s (itself a nod to their 1890s origins) - although its horribly marred by the logo of an obscure online gambling firm ... https://t.co/8nOxXgO1s4

@northumbriana As far as sponsorships, for the most part the only commerical logos on uniforms in any collegiate or top-level professional league here, regardless of sport, are of the jersey manufacturer. Soccer is the main exception, though the NBA started allowing small logos during playoffs.

@northumbriana University teams have increasingly frequently been introducing special event/extra alternate/"throwback"/etc uniforms that are worn at only one or two games each year, presumably to drive merchandise revenue. The NFL (and baseball/basketball) also do it to a more limited extent.

@bennyfactor do gridiron teams usually change their strips? I always thought that was one area of American sport that was (surprisingly) untouched by commercialism ... (unlike the UK where we've had shirt sponsors since the 70s)
Is this the price the world has to pay to finally have ND play UM again? Even though that is the literally only good American football game in the universe, I'm not sure it's worth it.
